" Oh
papa " said Jack "
Jack " is this curious
grows so abundantly on the grass here
I know it well by sight "
I do not know its name
It is a of horse-tail quite hollow
see quite hollow
how the stem is marked with lines

The fruit is borne at the top of the plant ( _ a _ ) spores
see
as I shake it
what a quantity of dust comes from it
this dust is the spores
as they are called
each spore is of an oval form with four elastic threads
If I were to put some of this dust on a glass slide
I look at it under the microscope
I should see a curious sight
The four threads would be spread out
if I were to breathe on the glass
these threads would coil
themselves round the oval body
as soon as the effect of the moisture had passed away
the threads would shoot out again in the same position as they were at first
as they were at first

as if it were
The stems are of two kinds , fertile and unfertile
you have in your hands
the one is a fertile
the one appears only in the spring
the unfertile ones have no dust-like fruit
the unfertile ones have numerous jointed branches
growing in rows
the unfertile ones whorls
as they are termed
the unfertile ones round them
they remain throughout the summer
in some places form quite a thick cover
Feel
how rough the stem is
this is to the presence of a quantity of silex or flint in it
on this account some of the species are used for polishing purposes
One kind under the name of " Dutch rushes " is imported from Holland , being used for polishing mahogany , ivory , metal , & c
being used for polishing mahogany , ivory , metal , & c
The horse-tails for the most part grow in moist ground in ditches on the borders of lakes
some however are in corn fields on the roadside
In this country they do not attain a height of more than a few feet
in tropical countries one two species grow to the height of sixteen feet or more
I will try a few Hydræ
I catch
Strange animals indeed they are
strange is their
but let
us catch a few first
Nothing yet in my bottle like a hydra
now we have one two
You see a small creature
sticking to the stem of a bit of duckweed
around its mouth are five six little
At present they are contracted
but the hydra is to lengthen them out
when they appear as long , thin lines , which are used as the creature 's fishing-lines
long thin lines are used as the creature 's fishing-lines
it is not much than a pin 's head at present
it can stretch its body out
as it does its lines
I will take a handful of duckweed into this bag
I put it
I dripping wet
when we get home
we will place the whole in a glass vessel full of water

In the course of half an hour or so we shall no doubt see several hydræ probably of different species in various attitudes some hanging loosely down throwing out their arms tentacles many times longer than their bodies others shooting up their arms right above their heads others floating on the surface of the water , their tail-ends sticking out serving to keep them from sinking some of a beautiful grass-green colour , others light brown or flesh colour , others almost white , others red
others erecting themselves in graceful curves
others contracted
looking like miniature dabs of jelly
others attached head tail to the side of the glass
These creatures may be cut into several parts
each part will grow again into a perfect animal
young ones bud of the sides of the parents
Some have said
that they can be turned inside out
they find no inconvenience whatever from the operation
" asked Willy "
" But how could anybody manage to turn so small a thing as a hydra inside out "
It does seem an impossible task
I confess
a man must have much skill patience to enable him to accomplish it
However I will give you the description of an attempt made many years ago by a celebrated naturalist of Geneva , named Trembley , who made the hydræ or fresh-water polypes a study for many years
made many years ago a celebrated naturalist of Geneva
named Trembley
a celebrated naturalist of Geneva made the hydræ fresh-water polypes a study for many years
This is "
what Trembley says
I begin giving a worm to the polype
by giving a worm to the polype on which I wish to make an experiment
when it is swallowed
I begin operations
It is not to wait
till the worm is much
I put the polype in a little water in the hollow of my left hand
the polype stomach is well filled
I then press it with a small forceps nearer to the tail end than to the head
nearer to the tail end than to the head
In this way I push the swallowed worm against the mouth of the polype , which is thus forced to open
the polype is thus forced to open
again slightly pressing the polype with my forceps I cause the worm partly to come out from its mouth
the worm thus draw out with it an equal part of the end of its stomach
coming out of the mouth of the polype
The worm forces it to enlarge itself considerably
especially if it comes out
doubled up
When the polype is in this state
I take it gently out of the water disturbing anything
I place it on the edge of my hand , which is simply moistened , so that it may not adhere too closely
the edge of my hand is simply moistened
so that it may not adhere too closely
I oblige it to contract more more
this also enlarges the stomach mouth
The worm then is partly coming of the mouth keeping it open
out
I then take in my right hand a hog bristle rather thick without a point
I hold it
as one holds a lancet for bleeding
I bring its thickest end to the hind end of the polype
I push it
making
it enter into its stomach , which is the more easily done as in that part it is empty and much enlarged
its stomach is the more easily done much enlarged
as in that part it is
I push on the end of the hog 's bristle , which continues to invest the polype
the hog bristle continues to invest the polype
When it reaches the worm
the worm holds the mouth open
it either pushes the worm at last "
it passes by its side
it comes out by the mouth , the polype being thus completely turned inside out
being thus completely turned inside out
